1123971741389344773.text: Despite the two crashes, Boeing still does not recommend any additional training for pilots on MCAS, instead encouraging pilots to simply read the manual.pic.twitter.com/xnkaU1Punw

1123970436876910593.text: The FAA also did not examine MCAS’s power or authority over pilots because it deemed the system had a low “composite risk value” — illustrating the agency’s lack of understanding of the software.pic.twitter.com/v1e3Lz3MXW

1123969025741074432.text: The Federal Aviation Administration has admitted to being incompetent when regulating software, and as a policy, allows plane manufacturers to police themselves for safety. Nowhere in its certification of the 737 MAX is MCAS mentioned.pic.twitter.com/UCuqxRGAKw

1123967641461370886.text: Since the 737 MAX was the same plane type as its predecessors, pilots would only need a 2.5-hour iPad training to fly its newest iteration — and nowhere in that 2.5 hours was a mention of MCAS, or how to disable it.pic.twitter.com/VTBdvSSzlt

1123966462887116800.text: Nearly a decade ago, in response to Airbus’ fuel-efficient plane, Boeing rushed the competing 737 MAX to market as quickly as possible, and sold a record-breaking 3,000 MAXes worth over $100 billion even before the first prototype took to the skies.pic.twitter.com/tryHU87iRm
